**G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this civil action pursuant to **G.L. c. 212, § 4**, which grants the Superior Court jurisdiction over civil actions where the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1**.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester County under **G.L. c. 223, § 1** because the events giving rise to this claim occurred in Worcester, Massachusetts.

**M.G.L. c. 84, \u00a7\u00a7 15\u201324*.proposition: The sidewalk abutting the property was the responsibility of the Defendant, as the owner and person in control of the premises, to maintain in a reasonably safe condition. See **M.G.L. c. 84, §§ 15–24**.

**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner owes lawful visitors and those reasonably expected to be present upon the premises a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition. See **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); **Dos Santos v. Coleta**, 465 Mass. 148 (2013).
**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (19.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is from a concurrence and focuses on the continued separate treatment of trespassers, not on defining the duty owed to lawful visitors. However, Mounsey v. Ellard as a whole is the landmark Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and recognizing a general duty of reasonable care to lawful entrants and those reasonably expected to be on the premises. Thus, while this specific excerpt does not state the rule, the case itself supports the proposition.
**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (19.relevant_excerpt: (From the main opinion, not provided in the excerpt): The court in Mounsey held that ‘the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees should no longer be determinative of the occupier’s duty of care’ and that an occupier owes ‘a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors.’ (Paraphrased from the main holding of Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).)

**Dos Santos v. Coleta**, 465 Mass. 148.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner owes lawful visitors and those reasonably expected to be present upon the premises a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition. See **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); **Dos Santos v. Coleta**, 465 Mass. 148 (2013).
**Dos Santos v. Coleta**, 465 Mass. 148.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the general Massachusetts rule that an owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises, including the obligation to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition, citing Mounsey. Dos Santos does not change that baseline duty; it applies and elaborates on it in the context of open and obvious dangers and the duty to remedy, so the case appropriately supports the cited general proposition about a landowner’s duty to lawful visitors.
**Dos Santos v. Coleta**, 465 Mass. 148.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. Id. at 743. This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973).”

**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Ma.proposition: Defendant had both actual and constructive notice of the icy sidewalk and failed to take reasonable measures to correct or warn of the hazard, in violation of her duty of care. See **Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Mass. 368 (2010); **Sullivan v. Brookline**, 435 Mass. 353 (2001).
**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether the defendant had actual or constructive notice of an icy sidewalk and failed to take reasonable measures to correct or warn, i.e., the notice and breach components of a negligence claim. Papadopoulos does not decide that Target had actual or constructive notice or that it failed to act reasonably; instead, it abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and holds that general reasonable-care principles apply to snow and ice. The Court remands precisely so that negligence, including any notice issues, can be evaluated under that new standard, so it is not authority for the specific proposition about the defendant’s notice and breach in this or any other case.
**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

**Sullivan v. Brookline**, 435 Mass. 353.proposition: Defendant had both actual and constructive notice of the icy sidewalk and failed to take reasonable measures to correct or warn of the hazard, in violation of her duty of care. See **Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.**, 457 Mass. 368 (2010); **Sullivan v. Brookline**, 435 Mass. 353 (2001).
**Sullivan v. Brookline**, 435 Mass. 353.support_reasoning: This Sullivan v. Brookline decision concerns reinstatement of a disabled police retiree and the interaction between G.L. c. 32, § 8(2) and G.L. c. 31, § 39. It does not involve premises liability, icy sidewalks, notice of hazardous conditions, or a duty to remedy or warn of ice. Citing this case for the proposition that a defendant had actual and constructive notice of an icy sidewalk and breached a duty of care is inaccurate and unrelated to the issues actually decided.
**Sullivan v. Brookline**, 435 Mass. 353.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff, a twenty-year retiree of the Brookline police department (department), raises two issues through his petition for reinstatement: first, what standard should apply in evaluating a retiree’s fitness to return to full employment; and second, whether a long-term retiree must complete retraining before becoming entitled to reinstatement. To answer these questions this court must interpret G. L. c. 32, § 8 (2), and G. L. c. 31, § 39.

**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (19.proposition: Defendant’s failure to sand, salt, or adequately clear the walkway constitutes negligence under Massachusetts common law. See also **Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (1980); **Toubiana v. Priestly**, 402 Mass. 84 (1988).
**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (19.support_reasoning: Young v. Garwacki is a landlord‑tenant premises liability case about a defective porch railing, not about snow/ice or a failure to sand, salt, or clear a walkway. Its holding is that landlords owe a general duty of reasonable care in maintaining rented premises, including areas within the tenant’s control, but it does not involve or discuss walkway maintenance or winter conditions. At most it supplies a broad duty-of-care framework; it does not specifically establish that failure to sand or salt a walkway is negligence under Massachusetts law.
**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.” (380 Mass. at 169).

**Toubiana v. Priestly**, 402 Mass. 84 (.proposition: Defendant’s failure to sand, salt, or adequately clear the walkway constitutes negligence under Massachusetts common law. See also **Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162 (1980); **Toubiana v. Priestly**, 402 Mass. 84 (1988).
**Toubiana v. Priestly**, 402 Mass. 84 (.support_reasoning: The case does not involve snow, ice, sanding, salting, or clearing of a walkway. It concerns an allegedly dangerous freight elevator and whether the landlord was negligent in failing to provide a solid ceiling, warning signs, a slack rope device, or an operator. The SJC ultimately holds that the defendant’s omissions did not constitute negligence under Massachusetts common law. Thus, Toubiana v. Priestly does not support a proposition that failure to sand, salt, or clear a walkway constitutes negligence.
**Toubiana v. Priestly**, 402 Mass. 84 (.relevant_excerpt: “The question to be decided, then, is whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that, in view of all the circumstances, an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps, not taken by the defendant, to prevent the accident that occurred. We are satisfied that, on the evidence, no such conclusion was warranted. … It follows that the defendant’s failure to adopt either of those measures did not constitute negligence.”

**Ulwick v. DeChristopher**, 411 Mass. 4.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries. See **Ulwick v. DeChristopher**, 411 Mass. 401 (1991); **Janosz v. J.C. Penney Co.**, 324 Mass. 697 (1949).
**Ulwick v. DeChristopher**, 411 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: The opinion does not hold that the defendant’s failure to act was the direct and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. Instead, the court holds there is no common-law duty on this social host where he neither served nor provided liquor, and therefore no basis for negligence liability at all. The discussion of causation appears only in a generic description of negligence elements (duty, breach, causation, damages), and the court ultimately finds no duty, not that any failure to act caused the injuries.
**Ulwick v. DeChristopher**, 411 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: "Any liability on the defendant's part in such a situation must be grounded in the common law of negligence...meaning that the plaintiff has the burden of proving each and every element of that claim: duty, breach of duty (or, the element of negligence), causation (actual and proximate) and damages.... Since no common law duty exists here, it follows that the statutes relied on by the plaintiff do not of themselves create a cause of action in tort."

**Janosz v. J.C. Penney Co.**, 324 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s failure to act was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries. See **Ulwick v. DeChristopher**, 411 Mass. 401 (1991); **Janosz v. J.C. Penney Co.**, 324 Mass. 697 (1949).
**Janosz v. J.C. Penney Co.**, 324 Mass..case_name: Gleason v. Hardware Mutual Casualty Co.
**Janosz v. J.C. Penney Co.**, 324 Mass..support_reasoning: This opinion concerns contract and insurance law, specifically whether an earlier equity action created res judicata between an insured and his insurer regarding coverage. It does not address causation in tort, nor does it discuss whether a defendant’s failure to act was the direct and proximate cause of a plaintiff’s injuries. The case is therefore not proper authority for the proximate-cause proposition cited.
**Janosz v. J.C. Penney Co.**, 324 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "The doctrine of res judicata is a rule of public policy founded on the established principle that it is in the interest of the parties and for the public welfare that litigation once decided on its merits should end." (324 Mass. at 698).

**Barry v. Beverly Enterprises\u2011Mass.proposition: Plaintiff’s injury was a foreseeable result of Defendant’s breach of duty, and Plaintiff exercised reasonable care at all times relevant. See **Barry v. Beverly Enterprises‑Mass., Inc.**, 418 Mass. 590 (1994); **O’Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 201 (2000).
**Barry v. Beverly Enterprises\u2011Mass.support_reasoning: Barry holds that the plaintiff failed to prove the defendant breached its duty because there was insufficient evidence that the defendant knew or should have known of the icy condition; the court orders judgment notwithstanding the verdict for the defendant. The opinion does not find that the plaintiff’s injury was a foreseeable result of a breach, nor does it address or affirm that the plaintiff exercised reasonable care at all times; instead it concludes there was no actionable breach at all. Using Barry as authority that the injury was a foreseeable result of a breach and that plaintiff exercised reasonable care misstates the case’s holding.
**Barry v. Beverly Enterprises\u2011Mass.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e conclude that the defendant’s motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict should have been allowed because the evidence, viewed in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, was not sufficient to warrant an inference that the defendant violated the duty of reasonable care that it owed to the plaintiff. … Specifically, we hold that the evidence did not warrant an inference that the defendant knew, or in the exercise of reasonable care should have known, of the icy condition that caused the plaintiff’s fall.”

**O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 2.proposition: Plaintiff’s injury was a foreseeable result of Defendant’s breach of duty, and Plaintiff exercised reasonable care at all times relevant. See **Barry v. Beverly Enterprises‑Mass., Inc.**, 418 Mass. 590 (1994); **O’Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 201 (2000).
**O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 2.support_reasoning: The opinion in O’Sullivan v. Shaw does not support the proposition that the plaintiff’s injury was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s breach, or that the plaintiff exercised reasonable care. Instead, the court holds that the danger of diving into the shallow end was open and obvious, so the landowners owed no duty to warn and therefore could not be liable; the analysis stops at duty and does not find a breach or discuss plaintiff’s care as a basis for liability. Thus, citing O’Sullivan for the proposition that plaintiff’s foreseeable injury followed from defendant’s breach and that plaintiff acted reasonably misstates the case’s holding.
**O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 2.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that, because the danger of diving into the shallow end of a swimming pool is open and obvious to a person of average intelligence, the defendants had no duty to warn the plaintiff of this danger as a matter of law and, therefore, they could not be found liable for his injuries. The defendants’ motion for summary judgment was correctly allowed.”

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6D**.proposition: As a result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff has sustained personal injuries, pain and suffering, lost wages, and medical expenses, and will continue to sustain such damages into the future. See **G.L. c. 231, § 6D** (governing recovery of damages for personal injury).

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 6C**.proposition: Costs of suit and applicable interest pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B, 6C**;
